Title.evidence: This randomized clinical trial provides high-level evidence for mesh repair for umbilical hernias less than or equal to 2 cm.

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomized, controlled, parallel-group, double-blind, multicentre trial across six Swedish surgical units is comparing 4 × 4 cm macroporous lightweight onlay mesh repair with conventional suture repair for primary elective umbilical hernias less than or equal to 2 cm.

Participants.evidence: A randomized, controlled, parallel-group, double-blind, multicentre trial across six Swedish surgical units is comparing 4 × 4 cm macroporous lightweight onlay mesh repair with conventional suture repair for primary elective umbilical hernias less than or equal to 2 cm.

Intervention.evidence: A randomized, controlled, parallel-group, double-blind, multicentre trial across six Swedish surgical units is comparing 4 × 4 cm macroporous lightweight onlay mesh repair with conventional suture repair for primary elective umbilical hernias less than or equal to 2 cm.

Objective.evidence: The aim of this study was to report the preliminary results of a trial investigating surgical-site occurrences in suture versus mesh repair for umbilical hernias less than or equal to 2 cm.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome of the trial is recurrence at 3 years, whereas secondary outcomes (the focus of this study) include surgical-site occurrences and pain intensity at 30 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Intraoperative centralized web-based randomization ensured allocation concealment.

Blinding.evidence: A randomized, controlled, parallel-group, double-blind, multicentre trial across six Swedish surgical units.

Number_Randomised.evidence: From February 2020 to January 2024, 290 participants were randomly assigned to either suture or mesh repair.

Number_Analysed.evidence: After exclusion and loss to follow-up, the remaining population for analysis was 144 participants for suture repair and 135 participants for mesh repair.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Surgical-site occurrences (Clavien–Dindo grade greater than or equal to I) affected 32 mesh repair participants (23.7%) compared with 26 suture repair participants (18.1%), without any significant increase in surgical-site occurrences for mesh repair (OR 1.39 (95% c.i. 0.78 to 2.51)).

Harms.evidence: Surgical-site occurrences (Clavien–Dindo grade greater than or equal to I) affected 32 mesh repair participants (23.7%) compared with 26 suture repair participants (18.1%).
